raw_response:
{
  "q3_revenue": "180,169",
  "q3_operating_income": "17,422",
  "q3_diluted_eps": "1.95",
  "q4_revenue_guidance": "206.0 - 213.0",
  "q4_operating_income_guidance": "21.0 - 26.0",
  "summary": "Q3 2025 Financial Snapshot
Amazon reported Q3 2025 total net sales of $180,169 million and operating income of $17,422 million, essentially flat Y/Y on operating profit despite double-digit top-line growth. Diluted EPS was $1.95, reflecting net income of $21,187 million, which benefited from sizable non-operating gains (including $10,186 million in other income/expense, net) tied to investment-related marks and reclassifications (notably Anthropic-related gains cited by management).  

Segment Performance and Key Drivers
Growth was broad-based across the three reporting segments, led by AWS. North America delivered net sales of $106,267 million (+11% Y/Y) but operating income declined to $4,789 million, driven by higher fulfillment, technology/infrastructure, and other operating costs, including a $2.5 billion FTC legal settlement charge recorded in other operating expense and company-wide severance costs from planned role eliminations. International net sales were $40,896 million (+14% Y/Y) with operating income of $1,199 million, pressured by higher shipping and fulfillment costs (also including severance). AWS was the key profit engine: net sales rose to $33,006 million (+20% Y/Y) and operating income increased to $11,434 million, supported by higher customer usage but partly offset by elevated infrastructure investment and severance costs.  

Strategic/Operational Highlights
Management emphasized accelerating AI-driven demand in AWS and rapid product velocity across the AI stack, including strong adoption of Trainium2 (described as fully subscribed and a multi-billion-dollar business), scaling of major AI compute capacity (e.g., “Project Rainier”), and continued expansion of AWS infrastructure/power capacity (+3.8 gigawatts added over the last 12 months). In Stores/retail operations, leadership highlighted ongoing fulfillment network improvements aimed at faster Prime delivery speeds and expanded same-day grocery reach (targeting 2,300+ communities by year-end). 

Costs, One-Time Items, and Risks
Quarterly operating income was negatively impacted by two notable items: a $2.5 billion FTC settlement charge and approximately $1.8 billion of estimated severance costs from planned role eliminations, impacting all three segments. Key risk framing in company disclosures continues to include macro demand variability, FX, competition, regulatory/legal outcomes, and execution risks in fulfillment and data center optimization; guidance also explicitly assumes no additional material acquisitions, restructurings, or legal settlements.  

Q4 2025 Outlook
For Q4 2025, Amazon guided net sales of $206.0–$213.0 billion (10%–13% Y/Y growth), assuming a ~190 bp FX tailwind, and operating income of $21.0–$26.0 billion (vs. $21.2 billion in Q4 2024). The implied setup suggests continued strong AWS-led growth with profitability dependent on peak-season execution and cost discipline amid elevated infrastructure and restructuring-related spend. "
}

parsed_response.summary:
Q3 2025 Financial Snapshot
Amazon reported Q3 2025 total net sales of $180,169 million and operating income of $17,422 million, essentially flat Y/Y on operating profit despite double-digit top-line growth. Diluted EPS was $1.95, reflecting net income of $21,187 million, which benefited from sizable non-operating gains (including $10,186 million in other income/expense, net) tied to investment-related marks and reclassifications (notably Anthropic-related gains cited by management).  

Segment Performance and Key Drivers
Growth was broad-based across the three reporting segments, led by AWS. North America delivered net sales of $106,267 million (+11% Y/Y) but operating income declined to $4,789 million, driven by higher fulfillment, technology/infrastructure, and other operating costs, including a $2.5 billion FTC legal settlement charge recorded in other operating expense and company-wide severance costs from planned role eliminations. International net sales were $40,896 million (+14% Y/Y) with operating income of $1,199 million, pressured by higher shipping and fulfillment costs (also including severance). AWS was the key profit engine: net sales rose to $33,006 million (+20% Y/Y) and operating income increased to $11,434 million, supported by higher customer usage but partly offset by elevated infrastructure investment and severance costs.  

Strategic/Operational Highlights
Management emphasized accelerating AI-driven demand in AWS and rapid product velocity across the AI stack, including strong adoption of Trainium2 (described as fully subscribed and a multi-billion-dollar business), scaling of major AI compute capacity (e.g., “Project Rainier”), and continued expansion of AWS infrastructure/power capacity (+3.8 gigawatts added over the last 12 months). In Stores/retail operations, leadership highlighted ongoing fulfillment network improvements aimed at faster Prime delivery speeds and expanded same-day grocery reach (targeting 2,300+ communities by year-end). 

Costs, One-Time Items, and Risks
Quarterly operating income was negatively impacted by two notable items: a $2.5 billion FTC settlement charge and approximately $1.8 billion of estimated severance costs from planned role eliminations, impacting all three segments. Key risk framing in company disclosures continues to include macro demand variability, FX, competition, regulatory/legal outcomes, and execution risks in fulfillment and data center optimization; guidance also explicitly assumes no additional material acquisitions, restructurings, or legal settlements.  

Q4 2025 Outlook
For Q4 2025, Amazon guided net sales of $206.0–$213.0 billion (10%–13% Y/Y growth), assuming a ~190 bp FX tailwind, and operating income of $21.0–$26.0 billion (vs. $21.2 billion in Q4 2024). The implied setup suggests continued strong AWS-led growth with profitability dependent on peak-season execution and cost discipline amid elevated infrastructure and restructuring-related spend.
